Before I begin with the blood splat of the upcoming review for Friday the 13th Part VIII- Jason Takes Manhattan, I will review this film for any future newbies. 

He said that as he rejoices in criticizing Friday the 13th Part VIII- Jason Takes Manhattan. It's been a few years since Jason was done for in the disappointing New Blood. Now, Jason has been brought back to life due to an accidental cut in an electrical cord under the lake. The electric surges through his body bring him back to life. Before this happens, we get views of New York City from the ocean view to the alleys, time square, and subways. It is then title appears with cheesy and horrible 80s music in the background. Wow, Jason will go to Manhattan? This was a period when variety began to consume in the Friday the 13th films. After a fresh start, Jason went on to battle telekinetic girl right before going to New York City and sent to perdition. 

3D had a lot of insulting 3D and amateurish, but it was iconic. 
Final Chapter was great in special effects, but its characters were inept. 
New Beginning was a lot of fun despite the awfulness. Three cheers for gratuitous nudity. 
Jason Lives franchise brought him back to life with new powers and super strength. It was written and directed by Tom McLoughlin. 
New Blood installment removed any sort of intelligence for the characters and mixed in with a cheesy 80s teenage drama with a Carrie White girl rip-off. 
Friday the 13th has a lot of improvements as it takes material from the first four and gives Jason a personality although it still lacks suspense and doesn't bring anything new. 

Now, we have Jason Takes Manhattan which a title like that would bring a lot to mind like seeing Jason walking around the streets of Manhattan slashing and dicing. Heck, he could kill scores of folks while going on to ice ring to take on the Red Wings. As that happens, a number of movie trivia and homage happens with scenes you'll say Taxi Driver, King Kong, Death Wish, and plenty of other great films. As I tell you all this, there is one scene when Jason stops and looks. He stands tall as he sees a billboard with a hockey mask. Yes, this should have been Jason's finest moment in the series and maybe in the movie, but once again, bad writing, acting, and directing stand in the way. Incompetence rules this flick throughout the entire time as the film spends 1 and 10 minutes in a boat while 15 minutes in a studio built alley and 5 minutes in Manhattan. The results are rather humiliating than thrilling or fun. Fans and critic are pretty much in the same page when it comes to it, so why review it anyways? The answer is not to warn people for they have been warned obviously enough, but to give folks a clear insight what I thought about and to complete the Friday the 13th film series. Will I buy it? As completist (not a real word), yes I will buy the deluxe edition since I want to complete the series with Michael Myers, Jason Voorhees, and Freddy Kruger (haven't published review). As you know, my recommendation is a no on this film unless you're a hardcore fan. The film's biggest sin is the wasted opportunity. 

The opening film has a tour on New York City although there are allegations that some of it looks like it's in Vancouver and that's coming from Entertainment Weekly. Anyways, the music plays and narration is given even though I thought the music was all wrong and crap. Anyways, the title appears and we move back into Camp Crystal Lake death place of Jason Voorhees. A boat is in the water and we see underwater that an anchor is trying to grip something. Anchor grips an electrical chord and cuts it giving a short power circuit around it. The noise startles two recent graduate students Jim (Todd Shaffer) and Suzie (Tiffany Paulsen), so Jim goes off to see what it was. Suzie sits in bed waiting for Jim but hears nothing from him and starts to worry as she begins to think about what Jim said. The thoughts revolve around Jason Voorhees and his existence ready to kill any teenager on Manhattan. Suzie walks to the doorway in a t-shirt and panties as pop comes Jim with a t-shirt. Suzie actually falls for the moronic prank as Jim tells her it was only a joke while sporting tighty whities (gag). The two have sex according to formula as Jason takes the hockey mask and arms himself with harpoon gun. He kills Tim and looks at him as Tim tries to make a dramatic and epic death pose. As for his girlfriend, she has taken off as Jason looks around the camp thinking she's gone! Where has she gone too? He walks around the deck and suddenly, wait, I found her! He opens the hatch kills the pleading and helpless Suzie. 

The following scene takes place in the dock as students get ready to part ways from the hometown to New York. One of the chaperones is Charles (Peter Richman) who comes off a strict man. It is there that we meet another group of high school stereotypes like the nerd, druggy, smart, athletic, macho, and so forth. These characters represent stolen stereotypes based on other popular 80s shows and movies. However, it is Rennie (Jensen Dagget) and Sean (Scott Reeves) the film will concentrate as they develop a relationship despite the Uncle Charles's reluctance. Anyways, the get ready for sail and one of the ship's crews notices a boat appearing in the middle of nowhere despite the presence of folks on the deck. The cockeyed guy does nothing, but tells the folks that they're all doomed. Anyways, the ship sets sails with Sean's father in charge. Originally, Sean was to command, but quit when his dad corrected him. This scene reflects scenarios done a lot better in cheesy episodes and movies about father and son. Anyways, the folks on the ship party, make out, shoot videos, and do drugs. The camera takes a little time to see what each person does right before being killed by Jason. Meanwhile, our final girl, Rennie is having visions and hallucinations of a boy haunting in an unconvincing ways that has me and you guessing have to do with Jason and her past. Jason spends his time around the boat killing folks in some cheap ways while showing audiences his ability to teleport. We have a scene where this Queensryche wannabe girl goes to a steam room only to torture a poor defenseless flying V. She spots Jason and runs downstairs. Jason stands there doing nothing and then appears at bottom of the steam inexplicably. However, it gets better as Jason avenges the flying v by whacking her. 

Everyone on board goes on without noticing her scream except for the cockeyed guy. He does nothing, but says the voyage is doomed without being derision or a drunk. He walks around saying that meanwhile Charles goes around inspecting bad behavior while being overprotective of Rennie as she has vision of a young boy. The captain of the ship and skipper get picked off along with the other folks. Finally, the corpses are discovered, but not in a Nosferatu homage. The guys gather up, so they can go out and kill Jason Voorhees as they arm themselves with weapons. I was annoyed with this because I knew the formula will prevent the folks from actually using their weapons although friendly fire happens. Jason goes off and kills everyone except for a few survivors that include chaperone Charles and Colleen students Sean, Rennie, Julius (thrown overboard), and Toby the dog. The crew escapes through a life and wander through the fog in a convincing scene as everybody sleeps and cheers when they see the Big Apple. 

Upon reaching Manhattan, they get up to the docks believing they are safe, but are ambushed by a two thugs. This trip to Manhattan will be an uneasy one. Rennie is taken and the rest of the group splits to find help. Rennie is injected with some form of drug. Five minutes later, she up on her feet and moving normal. I guess she was injected with some weak stuff. Jason goes off and kills the remaining survivors although avoiding the New Yorkers. It is in the studio built alley that we finally learn what's been bugging Rennie all this time. Her past secret is neither really shocking nor scary and has you noddin' uh-huh. We have Jason pursuing the survivors in different areas with my favorite scene that involves a moronic gag with a boom box that was actually filmed in Manhattan. Chaos and suspense starts to appear in the film. Rennie and Sean go into the sewers to escape him where the scene kills the momentum that was built. The scene involves Rennie dumping a bucket of toxic waste into Jason sending him screaming and taking his mask off. The face appearance of Jason becomes irritating and offensive to look at. The film ends in a horrible note that brings closure to Rennie and Jason Voorhees.  

Watching this flick, I believe writer and director Rob Hedden set out to destroy the franchise. If I knew this was going to be a stinker, I would have traveled back in time and force him to change the location to New Jersey. Jason Takes New Jersey with a scene involving Jason killing a man by pushing him into a bathtub filled with water, ha ha. So, this is just water! It's not just water. It's New Jersey water! Oh no! Aghhhhh! The guy dissolves in the New Jersey water along with a New Jersey death style. Kidding. The film's problem also revolves around the fact that the film takes much of in the boat; therefore, the flick is really Jason Terrorizes Love Boat. The fans and critics of the series know this by heart along with the unfortunate viewers who saw this, so it leads to a poor performance at the box office. The film ranks as one of the lowest in profits with a 5 million dollar budget. I'm not surprised. The characters are pretty much the same as the play the stereotype they're to play along with annoying performances and predictable outcomes. 

The film is wretched upon the weak acting throughout the entire film as characters will shout or say a line, but leave an awkward pause in the middle. Kane Hodder (Jason Voorhees) is nearly the only one who can act because he doesn't deliver a line throughout the film. Even Peter Richman does a terrible job, you think cause of his age he would do a decent job, but he stinks as well. I recently reviewed Halloween- the Curse of Michael Myers and that flick was incompetent, but Donald Pleascene was brought some light to the dying film with his performance. Here we have nearly nothing to look forward in the characters. The cockeyed geezer annoyed me, so did the kid playing Jason Voorhees. One scene, we see the boy with a deformed right eye, but then he appears with a deformed left eye. I got annoyed how we get a fake and poorly acted drowning scene with him. Also, I was pretty unsurprised with the repressed memory Rennie had as it is connected to Jason. I didn't care much for the gore or death scenes except for the death of Charles (we knew it was going to happen). I was ready to write it off, but a funny thing happen. The scenes of supposedly Manhattan and actual Manhattan came in and saved the film barely to avoid 1. I love a scene where one of the characters decides to fight Jason with a boxing technique. I noticed 2 comical things: 1. Julius was an amateur 2. Those punches were pi*sing Jason. I applauded the scene afterwards. The scenes have suspense in them as Jason pursues his target while taking New Yorkers as the mosquitoes that can't be bothered with. We get a great and stupid gag with a boom box scene as these "punks" are listening to rap. There is a fiasco scene where a waitress does a sleazy job at the emergency the kids ask her. This was all pretty fun to watch although I couldn't help noticed that the entire film was a wasted opportunity. Oh and on a special note, I love the logical errors surrounding the film as we see character getting wet from the ocean, but found completely dried in the next scene. 

As for writer and director Rob Hedden, I am very sure he had a vision, but he wasn't right for the job. Although it's not his fault and we shouldn't hunt him down, I call him to fiction world where a fate like Charles's characters can take place. The music was all wrong too.

For all my reviews visit my website

Please note that the rating above is possibly skewed by the ratings on this specific site. There might be a slightly different rating at the end.

Alright, time for some...fun??

This trailer (from my website)...this trailer represents Jason in a new place. He looks at with confusion, with sadness, with....HATE. Ain't nobody gonna stop Jason!!!!!!!...Or will they?...Alright, time for a little backstory. Paramount Pictures was done with Jason Voorhees for good. They figured if they continued, it would be 80's style films in the 21st century (not a bad idea nowadays.) They figured we would go to Friday the 13th: Part 9000: SOMEBODY BETTER GET HAPPY!!!!!!!!! So, they decided to take him out the right way. It was 1989, the finishment of the 80's. (Yeah, I said finishment.) Now, Jason was ready to go somewhere he would never go before. But would it foreshadow what happened in real life? This gets into the conspiracy that Freddy vs. Jason was planned from the beginning, but let's talk about that later.

So how does this movie fair? Well, it starts with something very unusual. In fact, the whole formula for a FT13TH movie is not followed that well, partially because Jason travels in this film. The introduction, however, is a completely broken commentary on how New York City lives. Just...trust me. But it does set a tone, saying "we're going somewhere new people." Or say "the final Jason." By now, true Jason fans were used to everything about Friday the 13th...but was to come. In fact, some say that NYC represents where the series went. I mean, we went from a serious horror film about a mom who had lost her child and vowed revenge, to JASON FIGHTING A PSYCHIC? As much as I loved New Blood, it needed to be put to rest. And what better way then to go the craziest route yet.

At first, you feel like the film is going to be extremely cheesy fun. Jason gets re awakened by lightning *cough*PARAMOUNT, HOW MUCH LIKE FRANKENSTEIN DO YOU THINK JASON IS!!!*cough*. Then, he pulls out not the heart, not the brains, not the intestines of a teenager...but what I think is an appendix!!! And I'm just like "...worst Friday the 13th special effect ever. I love it." For a good amount of time, the film remains cheesy. Usual teenager stuff, dealing with the popular peoples, people addicted to just about anything, whether it be their passion of career, drugs, etc. And of course, the evil dads. But it actually turns out to be a scary horror film, with a Metroid style feeling. Basically, Jason says "You guys are dead and there's nothing you can do about it." Technically, they could have called for aerial assistants. 

And in this film, you want certain people to live, and certain people to DIE. And, awesomely enough, your wish is granted....sort of. Oh, and if I didn't mention it, this film mostly DOESN'T take place in Manhattan. (STRIKE!) It takes place on a boat. *cough*I'M ON A BOAT!*cough*. And if calls for a great Metroid feeling of loneliness. Only you and other people just as strong as you haft to face an immovable object with no chance for help. I can't explain it well enough. Most likely because I was watching this at 9:30 P.M. after a really long day. We should have the whole month of October off of work and school. 

Anyways, the kills are so awesome. Just, awesome. Gory and crazy. Just how you love these kills. Of course, one of the most famous is where Jason chops a guys head off and it falls off a roof. That just tells you something! But you've heard enough about how scary and how slashey it is. What about the story? Well...ugh...I...ugh....*crawls under his bed*HELP ME!!!!!!!!!! Okay, for serious. There is a REALLY freaky scene that *SPOILERS* is where the character is driving a police car, there's music, it's fast, and all of the sudden the music just stops. It then goes by still pictures showing the girl running over Jason as a child. And Jason just stares and stands...it is the freakiest moment in all of Friday the 13th Paramount besides the original's ending. *SPOILERS OVER.*

And that's where it comes down to. This is my favorite Friday the 13th film besides the original. In fact *SPOILERS* Jason in child form makes several appearances throughout the whole film attacking the same girl. He appears as a ghost, as some sort of demon through a portalX5 through a mirror and holly $#!T. *SPOILERS OVER.* The storytelling in this film, while not that obvious, is the best since the original. And of course, the kills are as awesome as he11. You can tell where this is going. The funniest moment is where Jason sees a poster with a hockey mask, and him and the poster are compared. Just...awesome. It wouldn't be funny if it weren't for the fact it's a psychopathic killer who's having A Big Lipped Trumpet Playing Starving Children Opus Face Moment.

Also, this movie is incredibly fast paced compared to the other FT13TH films. Also, also, also, also. CAN I EVER STOP STAYING ALSO? This is patially because of the fact that the characters are NOT annoying, except for the ones that are meant to be annoying (whom die quickly.) And of course, to be a good film about New York City, you need a realistic interpretation of the raccoon trash can named The Big Apple. Check and Mate. And if all this isn't an overload of awesome, Jason's face is a acid trip destruction of Jar Jar Binx and Oscar the Grouch. I know that doesn't sound scary...but it is. (Is this review resembling my To Kill a Mockingbird review at all?) 

The ending scene... I can't explain it. The only way I can explain is that Jason finally realized there's more to life than to mindlessly kill over vengeance. And he...I'm not gonna spoil it. It's beautiful. Oh wait, was that the ending? I can't remember...yeah. That was the ending. Or was it? Look, it was 10:00 P.M. alright? 

Time for the victim. The slasher aspect? 4.5/5. The story telling aspect? 4/5. It averages to 4.25/5, but is reduced to 4/5 for not taking place in Manhattan that much. It's so awesome though, that I wish I didn't haft to do that. 

I, Da Ca$hman signing off...

Really bad again, barely watchable

Ugh, probably the worst Friday the 13th.  It should have been called "Jason on a Boat", because the 67% of the movie is on a boat and not in New York, which was a huge let down!  I was anticipating seeing Jason stalk the city streets instead of the woods and was interested in seeing how that was played, but this movie didn't do that at all.  There wasn't really any deep characters (as usual) and most of the killing was pretty tame.  I did enjoy when Jason took Julius' head right off with one punch, that was pretty classic.

Why do I do this to myself? Do I just enjoy torture? Mind you, the first few Friday the 13th films were bad, but they weren't god-awful. Not at first. But they go so far downhill it's incredible. Five minutes into Friday The 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan, I knew I was in for a shit-storm.

Alright. The movie opens with as song about New York City, joined by a montage of the Big Apple, and followed shortly thereafter by a sex scene with two characters I don't know or care about. How does all this tie together? It doesn't. Do we ever hear about these two teenagers engaged in sex after they get killed by Jason? Of course not.

During this opening, we get a long, drawn out bit of exposition for the storyline of Jason Voorhees. This is interesting because I cannot help but wonder what sad sap will attempt to join the Friday The 13th storyline eight films in. As though there is any story at all.
Something else I really loved about this opening: the girl who just watched her boyfriend(?) get killed didn't even look scared while waiting for Jason come get her. It looked like they left the camera running and she was just staring off into space and decided to throw that shot into the movie. This is the type of film making and acting that we're in for, my dear readers. So bare with me. Oh, and there's still 90 minutes left of this movie.

For the rest of the movie, the audience is graced with the presence of actors who seem to be reading from cue cards standing on a boat that's on its way to NYC. Oh yes. Don't let the title confuse you; this movie is not set in Manhattan. It's set on a boat going to Manhattan. An easy mistake I am sure.

In addition to this, we have completely unique characters that people who have watched the series will have never seen before--like the old man who's catch phrase is "You're all doomed! Doomed!" Ah, yes, isn't the dialogue just riveting?

This reminds me of the most overused line in slasher film history:

"Stop screwing/playing/goofing/fooling around, guys!"

Every. Single. Slasher. Film. Has. This. Line.
ENOUGH! Think up some new lines!

Yes, my dear readers, Jason Takes Manhattan has the worst screenplay for a Friday movie yet--and that is saying something. For starters, I didn't even know how many people were on the boat. Not only that, I didn't know anyone's name. I did not bother to learn one person's name, that's how captivating and enriching these characters are. All these teenagers' range of character goes all the way from "only caring about sex" to "only caring about sex and drugs."

I guess I wasn't the only one who didn't know anyone on this boat, though. Jason is killing people for a good forty or fifty minutes before anyone even notices that anyone's missing. And remember that this isn't set in cabins out in the woods this time. Now there is no rhyme or reason for why the other characters wouldn't realize that their friends are completely missing and/or dead.

Just as in the last movie, it amazes me that a movie as plotless as a Friday The 13th sequel would bother to have subplots. This one does, and I couldn't care less about any of them. Plus, they wouldn't tell a story! This film could not tell a story! I kept getting so frustrated that this movie would be so much more concerned with trying to be "creepy" than to just tell one goddamn story! Oh, and I put the word "creepy" in quotes because what this movie tries to pass as creepiness comes off instead as just plain goofiness. That's the level that we have reached, my dear readers. By the way, the only decent plot thread that the story used was stolen--almost word for word--from an episode of M*A*S*H.

You know, calling a film "Jason Takes Manhattan" and having the opening montage show clips of NYC would lead me to believe that this movie might, I don't know, take place in NYC. But I'm so use to being let down by the Jason films by this point, I don't even know that I'm going to bother getting upset by this. Did this film have the budget to sink a ship but NOT the budget to take place in NYC? Not that I care, really. This whole movie sinks. The acting's bad, the story's bad, the dialogue is bad... It does have a little bit of the "dumb fun" element in it, but it's really being stretched here. This movie just plain sucks.
1/10

Once again, Jason is brought back to life from the bottom of the lake to return in this 8th installment of the Friday series.  After wrecking havoc on the two sailors that unknowningly did the dastardly deed, he makes his way to a yacht bound for New York where a young girl with a history at Crystal Lake seems to attract his attention.  After a fire in the engine room takes place, they take off in an escape vessel and finally make it to New York.  But, Jason manages to once again find them.  Good thing he's not immune to toxic waste!

The cheesy and campy factors grows quite a bit with this film, from toxic waste melting Jason's face, to visions of a deformed boy appearing in mirrors and flashbacks to Crystal Lake, with the typical New York mugging and Jason returning back to the form of a normal boy, who's body we can only imagine is never picked up, more than once you'll realize your watching this only because Jason himself is still the slasher of choice, even in a sad storyline.

This is probably the worst movie in the Friday the 13th series, which is saying a lot. It seems like the studio hired a writer/director who had never seen these films. And by 1989 that's a little inexcusable. 

So the plot is about a group of high school graduates that are taking a cruise to New York for the graduation trip. Wish I went Crystal Lake High, I had to go to Hershey Park. Anyway Jason is brought back to life and decides to come along. Most of the teens are killed and then the surviving teens wonder around New York as Jason still pursues them. Eventually they end up in the NY sewer system where "toxic waste" is just casually dumped every night. This in turn "kills" Jason. THE END.

I just saved you an hour and a half. 

Here is my biggest problem with part 8. One of the characters in the film is afraid of water, because as a young girl her guardian pushed her into crystal lake to teach her how to swim. Once she's in the water a child 'Jason" is under the water trying to drown her. 
HERE'S THE PROBLEM, If you watch the other movies you'd know that "Jason" supposedly drowned in the 1950's. But actually he survived and lived in the woods. All the while his mom is killing counselors he's just kind of hanging back. And watching from the sidelines. Don't know why he did not come forward before hand but whatever. Anyway in parts 2-4 he is going on a rampage before Tommy Jarvis kills him in part 4. So we are lead to believe that before part 6 takes place Jason is in fact a real person. Not the supernatural zombie he becomes in part 6 and continues to be in part 7. So when in this film the little girl see's a young Jason trying to drown her it makes no sense because he shouldn't be this evil force. And when she was young Jason would have been in like his 20's. Anyway what I am trying to say is that in the illogical world of the Friday the 13th films, this one makes the least sense. 

(I might write a blog about how I am chronologically confused by this film series) 

Well until Jason Goes To Hell, where they don't even try to explain how he got back to Crystal Lake, even though he was destroyed by toxic waste in NEW YORK CITY. 

if you are a die hard fan of the film series I know you've seen this one, and I know it's your least favorite. If you've never seen it, I don't suggest seeing it first. I usually tell people to skip this one in the film series. But whatever

Part 8 is the beginning of the end for the Friday the 13th series and has one of the most misleading titles in cinema history. It's chock full of plot holes, terrible acting from the majority of the cast and some very poor kill scenes for a slasher film. It's obvious that film makers were running out of ideas and were struggling to think of anything new.

You could be forgiven for thinking that the plot line would focus on Jason stalking some teenagers on the streets of Manhattan, hence the title, sadly there is all of ten minutes screen time set in New York. Instead, we the majority of the plot takes place on a cruise liner containing a bunch of high school graduates from Crystal Lake celebrating with a trip to new York. Jason gets on board and begins his usual killing spree. This actually could have been an interesting plot line, a sort of Under Siege with a serial killer, sadly the execution was terrible.

Yet again Jason is brought back to life from the bottom of Crystal Lake by resurrection power of electricity. I will remember to get someone to zap me with 9000 volts of electricity when I die, problem solved. The first plot hole is a huge one, the main girl of the film supposedly saw Jason in Crystal Lake when she was a kid. Jason drowned in the 50's, it's now the 80's and she is still a teenager. Her time traveling skills were never explained. She is stalked by ghostly visions of Jason throughout the film, sometime he is deformed, sometimes isn't. Even though these scenes make no sense at least they try to evoke some kind of scary atmosphere. The kill scenes on the boat are original, a guitar and hot stones from a sauna are used, the problem is that they all happen off screen. There is almost zero gore, maybe the problems the previous film had with the MPAA were to blame for this.

Once we finally get to Manhattan the film picks up hugely. It's great fun seeing Jason stalk around New York with people ignoring him. It's fun and leaves you wondering why they didn't set the whole film there. We do have another problem though; somehow Jason seems to have developed the power of teleportation. One second he is on the streets, the next he is one the tenth story of a building with no explanation how he did it. The climax is very good and but again leaves you thinking what could have been.

Kane Hodder plays Jason very well and the makeup effects are top notch again. Sadly it's the misleading title, off screen deaths, poor script and poor acting that let the whole thing down.

This ain't no love boat, and Jason is on board with one thing on his mind. The last Paramount release of the Friday The 13th franchise is actually an overlooked enjoyable film. People have strongly criticized this film because of the title, the length and other issues not worth mentioning. Jason is a stowaway aboard a student boat charter as they set sail for New York City. The big question is will it get there??? umm, well a few will thats for sure. This by far the most laid back of all the Friday films,it pretty much builds up on the comedic effect that was showcased in Jason Lives! Except now, almost everything is done for comedic effect. I love this entry in this series because of that fact, it's a film return to key Friday The 13th elements and yet is the one that seems to take itself not seriously whatsoever. In my Book, this film would have been a better end to the series.

Well, here it is. The final film of the original 8 parter of the Friday The 13th series, the film that for the 2nd time was meant to end it all (of course they didn't). The film certainly doesn't live up to its title well, being more like "Friday The 13th Part 8: Shipwrecked" and as much hate as this one gets for being one of the worst, I wasn't able to hate this film. I still hold a great dislike for A New Beginning as the worst of the original 8 films. The film, once again, makes no effort to establish many of the characters well... hell, a bunch die before we even know who the hell they are, who cares? That said, it was a mediocre effort and most of the film is on a boat, so by the time New York makes its appearance, its quite late. It feels much longer than it needs to be because of this time it takes, and you begin to wonder why the hell it took place on a boat to begin with. The deaths are fairly satisfying, a bit bloodier than the censored 7th film, but still very cut down. Dammit, I wish I could see this shit uncut! Anyhow, the kills are okay, and no matter how stupid you think the plot is, it's about as exciting as you could get for a series that's already running itself dry by this time. I wasn't put off with the ending being Jason's final moment. It may have been debatable for the time since it was thought to be the last film, but I know it isn't, so I know this won't be the end. The toxic waste is a cop-out, but oh well, I can do with it. The movie fails to live up to its name which is why its disappointing, and the film drags without much excitement at times, but for the most part I sort of enjoyed it, and its a good change of locations from thew usual cabins on the lakeside stuff.

Kane Hodder is supposedly one of the better Jasons as well but I have to say I think he's awful.  Anyway a poor entry and a weird nonsensical ending, all in all, not great.

There was a long time that i honestly thought that this was none of the worst movies ever made (maybe in some ways it kind of is) but sitting down and watching this almost ridiculously terrible film with likeminded people who i love very much the night before Halloween time this year it's insanely cheesy pleasures bubbled finally to the surface of all the toxic waste, much like the rest of the fridays, this is a party movie, a get drunk and watch with all your horror or casual movie fan mates and family up for a laugh type experience. Dont get me wrong this movie is truly fucking bad, in ways that sometimes skirt well past the line of "so bad it's good" (well, well past) but fuck me if it isnt great fun! first lets go through everything crappy about and wrong with this cheap ass, rip off of a flick. Firstly there's the title, Jason Takes Manhattan, it should have really been called Jason spends an hour and a bit on a boat killing assholes and wanders around some dark alleyways before spending the last ten or so minutes in actual, identifiable New York City. The big apple itself proved such an expensive shooting location that the screen time of the city is prattled down to nearly nothing, when the boar full of teens do actually arrive at the city harbor they spend about half an hour running around dark, dank alleys ways that could have been shot in fucking Skagness for all anyone knows, and then after about five mins in Times Square (were Jason very lamely scares off some switchblade wielding, boombox playing 80's punks by pulling up his mask) we then end up in dreary subway tunnels that, once again, could have been and most definitely were filmed somewhere else( i think every inch of NY footage they shot is in this movie, just look at the opening credits bit) The other weird fucking thing is that Camp Crystal Lake is now Camp Ocean Mouth really, as the lake has turned into a huge, almost edge-less horizon surrounded by massive snow peaked mountains in the distance (where ever they shot this is actually quite stunning i must admit) and it connects to the ocean, "hmm, okay then"....and we have a almost ocean liner sized ship full of graduating teens setting sail from a huge dockland that has also materialized. Jason tags along of course, after hilarious resurrection by electric volts from a falty underwater power cable ( why did no one go in and retrieve his body?) Jason, now a waterlogged, gooey corpse, grabs onto the anchor and joins the party. He's certainly welcome to the roster of teen meat to butcher, horrible, awful characters all, even by the Friday The 13th series low standard of actual likable human beings. The kills are sort of all over the place in this one too, being one of the series most obvious and severe victims of the MPAA, sometimes you get no pay off to a kill scene build up, like for instance the nasty cokehead bitch, i needed to see her get hers, thats the whole point of her fucking existence in this movie, it's like sex without the climax. But on the other hand when u do actually see the kills they are often so outlandish and ridiculous (the boxing death is especially cartoonish) that you just have to cheer and laugh, plus there are SO many!! (this has the highest single body count of the franchise, Jason really dose kill a fuckload of unlikable folks in this film!) another thing worth pointing out is the outright dive into Nightmare On Elm Street type supernatural sequences and imagery, with the final girls weird, oddly executed connection to Jason and her bizzare visitations of a the undead killing machine in his drowned child form as a ghostly spectre, there.s some groovy effects (the mirror bit) but it's all very half baked and vague, even baffling, like Jason reverting to child form after being hit by an apparently rejuvenating tidal wave of toxic waste, the actual fuck? but like i said, watch it with the right people, in the right atmosphere and knowing what you can and should be looking get out of it (an amazingly trashy, bad, cheesy, poorly acted, cheap, tacky pisstake of a film, with much 80's amp value) and you must be drunk, like really drunk.

Re-watching this was not a pleasant experience. I really had to force myself to watch it and once I finally did it was almost painful to make myself sit through the entire thing. Continuity is probably the film's biggest flaw. When we see young Jason drown, he looks like a normal little boy. Whenever Rennie sees him, however, he suddenly looks like he has down syndrome and like somebody beat him with a 2x4 made from every ugly branch they could get a hold of. On top of that, he pretty much has a different appearance every time Rennie sees him. Then there's the whole Crystal Lake leading into the ocean thing and the ending. Heavens, the ending is just a clusterfuck of retardism. The script isn't so hot either. Julius is probably the best example. After Wayne asks him what weapon he's going to take after they realize Jason is on the ship, Julius replies, "Nothing," then pauses for a moment before following with, "...but this gun." The kills were also lacking. Jason takes a guitar to a girl's head and throws a guy onto an antenna. That's about as inventive as we get this time around. The one enjoyable factor of the film is Kane Hodder as Jason. The scene in Times Square is probably the highlight of the film. It's disappointing that the last film with "Friday the 13th" in the title is so bad.

The Paramount years for the series ends with a whimper with this low budget waste of time. An intriguing premise is never realized because the budget would not allow for more than one night of filming in NY. The rest of the film was shot in Toronto. The cast is kept minimal as well. The entire crew of a cruise ship consists of the captain, a first mate and  one crazy crewman who spends most of his time predicting doom. Plus the school celebrating the graduation is about ten students strong including two chaperons and a dog.  Ironically the film is the longest in the series.

The weakest entry in the franchise, with a very inappropriate title and some bad acting. This should have been titled "Jason on a ship" because that's where Jason spent the majority of the film, while Manhattan was just the place for the slow-moving climax. And the fistfight with Jason on the rooftop is a very dumb way to solidify Jason's power, yes, he is very strong, we have already seen that in its long-spanning sequels, so why show him punching a man so strong that it decapitated him? Even Jason's face when unmasked looked like a cartoon character, and him turning into a kid again was nonsensical. And finally, putting a happy ending in a "Friday the 13th" film with a cheesy song is not applicable, because end sequences like that belongs to films like "Commando" and other early Schwarzenegger macho-actioners. The good thing with this film is its atmosphere, recreating New York's underbelly wonderfully, but other than that, this one's very weak.

Is considered by critics one of the worst entries of the F13 Saga. Perhaps the complaint was the faulty promise of taking NY as we only get to Manhattan in the final reel of the film. However I don't think this film was meant to be taken seriously. Yes there are plot holes, the continuity of the series stirs further away & logic really takes a big hit, but compared to other F13 films part 8 delivers interesting characters, original kills, humor & most of all itâs entertaining. 'Jason Takes Manhattan' as a title for this movie is a gigantic lie and they should really have called it 'Friday the 13th-I'm on a Boat'. Jason Takes Manhattan is utterly devoid of a plot as these films usually are, but unfortunately also falls short in several other areas which ultimately lead to it being recognized as possibly the worst film in the Friday franchise. Watching this flick, I believe writer and director Rob Hedden set out to destroy the franchise. If I knew this was going to be a stinker, I would have traveled back in time and force him to change the location to New Jersey. Jason Takes New Jersey with a scene involving Jason killing a man by pushing him into a bathtub filled with water, ha ha. So, this is just water! It's not just water. It's New Jersey water! Oh no! Aghhhhh! The guy dissolves in the New Jersey water along with a New Jersey death style. Kidding. The film's problem also revolves around the fact that the film takes much of in the boat; therefore, the flick is really Jason Terrorizes Love Boat. Heck, Manhattan looks a lot like Vancourer. The fans and critics of the series knew this by heart, so it leads to a poor performance at the box office. The film ranks as one of the lowest in profits with a 5 million dollar budget. Gee, I am not surprised. The characters are pretty much the same as the play the stereotype they're to play along with annoying performances and predictable outcomes. The film is wretched upon the weak acting throughout the entire film as characters will shout or say a line, but leave an awkward pause in the middle. Kane Hodder (Jason Voorhees) is nearly the only one who can act because he does not deliver a line throughout the film. Even Peter Richman does a terrible job, you think cause of his age he would do a decent job, but he stinks as well. A perfect example of this is Halloween- the Curse of Michael Myers and that flick was incompetent, but Donald Pleascene brought some light to the dying film with his performance. Here we have nearly nothing to look forward in the characters. The cockeyed geezer annoyed me, so did the kid playing Jason Voorhees. One scene, we see the boy with a deformed right eye, but then he appears with a deformed left eye. I got annoyed how we get a fake and poorly acted drowning scene with him. Also, I was pretty unsurprised with the repressed memory Rennie had as it is connected to Jason. I didn't care much for the gore or death scenes except for the death of Charles (we knew it was going to happen). I was ready to write it off, but a funny thing happen. The scenes of supposedly Manhattan and actual Manhattan came in and saved the film barely to avoid 1. I love a scene where one of the characters decides to fight Jason with a boxing technique. I noticed 2 comical things: 1. Julius was an amateur 2. Those punches were pi*sing Jason. I applauded the scene afterwards.The scenes have suspense in them as Jason pursues his target while taking New Yorkers as the mosquitoes that can't be bothered with. We get a great and stupid gag with a boom box scene as these "punks" are listening to rap. There is a fiasco scene where a waitress does a sleazy job at the emergency the kids ask her. This was all pretty fun to watch although I couldn't help noticed that the entire film was a wasted opportunity. Oh and on a special note, I love the logical errors surrounding the film as we see character getting wet from the ocean, but found completely dried in the next scene. As for writer and director Rob Hedden, I am very sure he had a vision, but he wasnâ(TM)t right for the job. Although itâ(TM)s not his fault and we shouldnâ(TM)t hunt him down, I call him to fiction world where a fate like Charlesâ(TM)s characters can take place. The music was all wrong too. Where's Agnostic Front when you need them?

After being burned in a fiery explosion and being pulled back into the bottom of the lake, Jason is resurrected by electricity to continue his murderous ways.  'Jason Takes Manhattan' brings the tried and true formula to a different locale with mixed results.  While the death scenes were innovative, the story was filled with cookie cutter characters and skimped on the Manhattan portion of the film.  It's hard not to laugh at the 'âclimatic' finale.  This one was on par with 'The New Blood' for me.  I wasn't totally bored, but I found myself longing for what once was an entertaining series.  The 'superstar' to be found in 'Part VII' is Kelly Hu in her film debut.

Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan
written and directed by Rob Hedden
based on characters created by Victor Miller
starring Kane Hodder, Jensen Daggett, Barbara Bingham, Peter Mark Richman, Saffron Henderson, Martin Cummins, Vincent Craig Dupree, Sharlene Martin

First of all, Jason doesnt exactly take Manhattan.  Two thirds of the way through the picture he does manage to visit there and continue in his delightful occupation, but it hardly constitutes full-blown mayhem which the title certainly promises.  What we have is a boatload of highschool seniors who are heading off to New York for their graduation.  As the film opens, a naughty couple are having sex aboard a boat.  They drop anchor and it inadvertently hits a powerline which awakens Jason yet again.  He manages to get on the pleasure cruise ship and subsequently fulfils his tender oath and begins slaughtering the unsuspecting ciphers one at a time.

This film adds an element that hasnt been as pronounced in earlier installments in the series.  Jasons victims bleat and plea for their lives more in this one and it adds a scintillating element to the story.  Best of all is a scene with the prissy and demonstrably conniving Tamara Mason is taking a shower and Jason comes in to seduce her.  While romance is thwarted and he ends up stabbing her with a shard from a broken mirror.  She cowers, whines, and otherwise puts on a pretty decent show before her unceremonious demise at the hands of her would be suitor.

Jasons kills are not very imaginative here and the film definitely lacks style points as the dull, burdensome killings continue unabated.  If only there was a single character worth getting thrilled over than these films would be more vital than they are.  Instead, we are left with characters who, as has almost always been the case, lack a discernible personality that elevates them above the typical kill victim.  Actually, there was a promising character early in the film but Jason spears him within the first ten minutes.  His performance suggests something more than what is generally to be expected in these films.

In this film a girl named Rennie Wickham (Daggett) is taking the cruise against the wishes of her Uncle Charles McCulloch (Richman), the groups chaperone.  She is haunted throughout the entire film by images of a young Jason who we learn apparently tried to pull her down after Uncle Charles pushed he off the dock intending to teach her how to swim.  She sees him everywhere and it truly twists her melon to the point that she can hardly tell what is real and what is imaginary at some point.  Rennie is a meek girl who is shy and the complete opposite of girls like Tamara, the prom queen who also enjoys a bit of nose candy now and again. Rennie is protected somewhat by Miss Colleen Van Deusen (Bingham), another chaperone who is constantly at odds with Uncle Charles.

One imagines terrific excitement once Jason finally lands in Manhattan but the result is pretty much a downer.  Yes, he takes care of a couple of junkie thugs, a cop, a bouncer at a bar, and several members of our merry crew who escaped when the ship caught on fire.  But he has so much opportunity to run wild in the streets cleaning up the sewage at every opportunity.  Instead, his focus remains strictly on the last two survivors and he chases them on a subway, through Times Square, and into the sewers.  Again, so many chances are not taken and the end is not particularly satisfying.  

There is something rather odd about watching Jason perform basic human tasks such as shutting a storage hatch.  Somehow the action is more pronounced, more deliberate, and not without its grace.  It shows an elegance about Jason which he mostly attempts to hide when hes off enjoying the sights and hacking up his chosen ones.  This film shows that Jason has a very focused mind and is not distracted easily by what is taking place around him.  He chases his victims with a strong sense of purpose and never gives up on them.  He knows what he wants and how to get it.  So very few nowadays can say the same thing which makes Jason into a character worth admiring on a certain level.  Hes very good at what he does although he does seem to run into some trouble now and again.  No matter, theres always lightning or power surges or a girls telekinesis to help him out of a tight scrape.

Overall, this film does nothing particularly novel and lacks some of the urgency that has made earlier films in the series more dynamic.  The deaths are rudimentary and the film simply does not live up to its title.  Ultimately, there is little character development which is nothing particularly new for the franchise.  Jasons killing spree seems truncated and could have enveloped so much more if that plot line were pursued.

The reason i love these films so much isnt for the great storylines, or the oscar worthy acting. Its purely for the kills and Jason is on great form, hacking his way through a boatload of students on there way to New York. Theres an air of 80s cheese about this entry, especially in the soundtrack (which is all poodle rock) and the especially funny new york gang members. Its a pretty refreshing idea to take Jason out of Crystal Lake and drop him into Manhatten. There are some pretty good kills to be had and its another enjoyable entry in the Friday the 13th series.

Friday the 13th Part 8 Jason Takes Manhattan is one of those movies in the Friday the 13th movie franchise that I didn’t like. It’s still not a favorite but there are aspects I appreciate more now than when it was first released. I vaguely remember before the film was released there’s a hotline set up for people who don’t like the fact that the movie had Jason going to NYC. Thought it would be bad press for the city.Yes, I call the number just to see what they say.PLOTA couple in a boat inadvertently resurrect Jason. He stows away on a boat where a senior class is on their way to New York City for their Senior Class trip. Also, one senior has memories of nearly drowning at Crystal Lake because of a young Jason. A handful of students and a couple of teachers escape the ship and Jason chases them through the streets of NYC.MY THOUGHTSWhile reading up on Friday the 13th Part 8 Jason Takes Manhattan, I read that the Director, Rob Hedden, doesn’t like the movie that much. He wanted to have most of the movie in New York, but the production company said no and wouldn’t give him the budget he needed. So instead of a movie with Jason in NYC the majority of the time, he is more on the boat. I think I would have also enjoyed the movie more if he was in NYC longer. I enjoyed the scenes in the city.As far as kills go, I liked J.J. ‘s (Saffron Henderson) with her guitar (I liked the whole music video feel of it). I also like the scene with Julius (Vincent Craig Dupree). Poor guy. If he was going against any normal human he would’ve beaten him down quite easily. But it’s Jason, and he loses his head. There are 20 kills in this movie. Most are on screen but not a lot of blood and gore.Kane Hodder (Jason), to break tension after a kill, would do a brief disco dance in full Jason getup to make the cast laugh. I wished they had it on tape. Would be funny to watch. Kane Hodder has been quoted as saying that one of the most fun parts of being Jason were the scenes in Times Square. He says that spectators were lined up and down the block watching the filming and he didn’t want to take off the mask to destroy their illusion of Jason. He said that every once in a while he’d turn his head and look at them and watch them all go crazy.Character wise, we get the typical teens: the jock, the **** the follower, the final girl, the love interest, and a mix of adults who listen and who are idiots. I don’t hate Rennie (Jensen Daggett) as the final girl, but she’s not a favorite either. Just meh. One fun fact is that it’s Kelly Hu’s feature film debut. Granted, the most famous actor’s first film is Kevin Bacon.Now to some of the issues with the movie. Ummm. The name is Jason Takes Manhattan yet the movie is barely in New York. I mentioned earlier that the issue was primarily the fault of the production company. Still, it would have been nicer if the movie was there. Also, the whole Jason child crap. Seriously, him as a child trying to drown Rennie? That makes no sense with the timeline. Jason wouldn’t be a child when Rennie was a child. Sigh, yes I know it’s a Friday the 13th movie but come on.This is the longest running time of the Friday The 13th films.The film takes place one year after the events of the prior film.If you want to see my other Friday the 13th reviews, click here: Friday the 13th Franchise.Let’s get into the rankings:Kills/Blood/Gore: 3/5Sex/Nudity: 1/5Scare factor: 2/5Enjoyment factor: 5/10My Rank: 2.75/5IMDB: 4.6/10Rotten Tomatoes: critics: 1.2/10 audience: 2.7/10Letterboxd: 2.2/5

rt_summary: Mass murderer Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is resurrected from the bottom of Crystal Lake. After he kills a passing boat's occupants, he stows away on a cruise ship filled with a high-school graduating class bound for New York City. Biology teacher Charles McCulloch (Peter Mark Richman) is on board with his niece, Rennie (Jensen Daggett), who has visions of Jason drowning as a child. They escape his bloody shipboard rampage, but, when Rennie and Charles reach Manhattan, Jason is close by.
meta_summary: A boatful of graduating high school students headed to Manhattan inadvertently bring Jason Voorhees along for the cruise.
